years and and I think that the key distinction of that was that the decision criteria was coded it was

single agent systems um what they do is they're using LLM to get advice um and

what we would call an an enrichment loop uh but that enrichment loop itself is a

just decisions but information that's generated in a distributed fashion and
if you architect the reasoning model in just the right way you get a higher form

a big part of this is that we're going to see that you can use LLMs to actually

now one of the things that was very compelling and telling for me was that

uh that you can get a structured output from that LLM uh and when we talk about
a structured enough way that is a combination of how the prompt is written
uh the structure of the prompt the context and semantic meaning that you

input parameters um and then a generic amount of information and the LLM will

system and so well once you realize that you've got these components available to you um now what you're doing is that
when you evaluate your cloudnative application you're rethinking how you
want that system to make its decisions and so um and really AI or LLM based
decision-m is applicable in areas where deterministic or rulebased approaches
fall short um so if you've got a rulebased system and the rules are constantly changing on you or that the
rule set is very large um or that it's really difficult to reason about the
rules then that's a situation where you can actually introduce LLMs as a
displacement or a replacement of that rulebased system um and you can teach it
how to make those decisions on your behalf because it's very good at synthesizing a wide range of inputs and
then making recommendations on that um and so if you have that sort of environment or um the decision- making
is tied to a lot of unstructured data uh LLMs are particularly good at you know
working within that environment so LLMs are the magic behind this in the
sense that they can do that reasoning that planning and analysis but an LLM is
just a brain so it doesn't have any memory and it can't perform any actions and so in order to do that in order for
an LM to be effective you put the LLM in an agent and the agent is actually
responsible for getting all the context that's necessary for the LM to make a good decision so it retrieves that
context it sends it to the LLM the LLM gives a response back and again the LM
can't invoke an API can't invoke a particular function and so again it's the responsibility agent based on what
the LLM says to actually invoke that function or call that API and then send
the results back into the large language model and finally agentic systems is the
term that we use when you have multiple agents and when you have multiple agents that are collaborating and interacting
that's actually how you actually can solve complex tasks so when you have all these agents
working together intelligence emerges um and this collaboration lets you tackle
these higher level goals reliably and I'll give a couple examples of how this
orchestration actually functions so one of the common patterns is prompt chaining so you may have imagine you
have an agentic system that's about taking some ideas for some marketing content and publishing on a blog in five
different languages so in order to do that you might have an agent that is focused on taking your marketing concept
or idea whatever topic it is and creating that content maybe iterating on that with a human and then once that
content is actually okay and approved it will send it to a dedicated translation
agent which is a different agent so that's sort of an example of how you're actually decomposing um a task into sort
of set of sequential tasks another pattern I just want to highlight is the synthesizer um pattern um where you
actually have an LLM that's actually orchestrating the actual planning so a good example of this would be if you
actually have a research task because in a research task you don't know in advance the actual agents that you will
want to do that research so based on the query your orchestrator agent may decompose that query into multiple
components and say well I'm going to delegate this to the internet search agent i'm going to delegate this to the
Salesforce search agent and delegate this to the Slack search agent or whatever it thinks is actually
appropriate so these different patterns are actually what enable Agentic systems
to actually tackle higher level problems and if you're if you realize these
workflows are these agents have to be orchestrated and agents are running on
computer systems and computer systems are just as reliable or unreliable as any other computer system and so in this
translation content agent when your content agent is creating that content if the server it's running on crashes
you need to be able to resume execution from the point in which it's crashing so
you need a durable execution workflow that also is traceable and audible and debugable all these different things
because you actually have a complex distributed system that you're orchestrating where all these agents are
really interacting together and you need to make sure that it always finishes and you can also debug situations where
you're having a problem so I want to talk about this
enrichment loop um that Tyler alluded to earlier so in a single agent this is the
heart of every single agent um architecture if you will um in an agent
we've talked about how you actually get a prompt right which is the input to a large language model you send the
results of that prompt to the LLM the LLM actually responds you save that
response in memory because the LLM is not going to remember on a subsequent call what it previously said so you save
that response in memory and the LLM typically will then respond with an API
to call or a tool or an action or summary and so then it's the responsibility of the agent to call that
tool it gets the results from that API call it adds the results to that prompt
and then it can call the LLM again and you can run this multiple times if you're calling multiple tools you're
iterating and that's actually how you get higher level reasoning so to call this into context um a
specific example imagine you're building a travel planning agent and the goal is an itinerary so you might send to it a
prompt that says "I want to book my travel um to some place to go skiing
it's May 1st." And so the LLM instead of just immediately responding with five
different ski areas may actually give you an invocation um give the agent an
invocation to check the ski conditions at these five different areas and maybe three of them are closed because it's
May and we're in the northern hemisphere at which point it responds back it gives the ski conditions of these five areas
and then the LM runs through another iteration of this loop and then can give you a recommendation so that's an
example of how this enrichment loop can actually create more powerful and nuanced reasoning um by just running
this loop multiple times yeah I I I just want to add in there Richard uh that you
know what's what's really important is that there's all kinds of different uh
tools and frameworks that help facilitate creating an agent uh but what's happening here is that you you're
really giving uh that LLM a really elaborate prompt and and inside that
prompt are instructions of available tools that it can make use of and when
the LLM figures out that it needs to make use of that tools the it comes back and tells the agent ah I need some
information from this tool here's the parameters to use it and so the agent not only does that work but then updates
the prompt as well So it gives a synthesized version of the prompt back to the LLM so that it can continue on
where it was and so the prompt keeps collapsing down keeps collapsing down until it's a final it's a final outcome
with that um and so the agent agentic framework has to automate all that sort
of interaction with memory interaction with tools and the reconstruction of the
prompt as it goes through that that looping process that's exactly right and and
this is where when we talk about how LMS are stateless that context that you're sending to the LM in the form of the
prompt is assembled from all these different sources right so you're getting knowledge and facts um from a

as past interactions if they're germanine from a memory database you might be calling APIs um and getting ski

event like maybe you're reading a webcam um that's a top of the ski mountain right so all these things are actually
being assembled by the agent to be sent to the large language model
now uh we talked about how you know reasoning is the coordination the
orchestrated coordination of multiple agents working with each other uh we
talked about agents as a enrichment loop and we've talked about how LLMs are
unreliable and stateless and so if you want to build an agentic system that has
both scale and is resilient you are dealing with a distributed system problem and uh you know this is
obviously an area that a takes near and dear to our heart and we provide a bunch of technology related to this uh but
there are specific distributed systems technologies that matter for each of these things um and when dealing with
LLMs the most powerful part of this is that uh they are stateless they tend to
be blocking activities their responses are chunked um and so you want to be
able to use a connectivity layer um that transitions that into an asynchronous
non-blocking invocation that the responses are no longer chunked but that they're event-based and streaming and
oftent times you're going to have uh be doing augmentation of real time data
even though the LLM itself is incredibly slow so you've got to be able to do
real-time ingestion augmentation of say audio video data and then back pressure
so that you don't overwhelm the LLM as you send um send the request over to it
and when you're dealing with agents now you have to recognize that many agent
enrichment loops have human in the loop interactions that's usually some sort of workflow construct associated with that
you're going to want that to be an event- driven architecture which means there's going to need to be retries circuit breakers and timeout um uh you
will want to think long and hard about how you're going to do the tool integration and whether your memory
database is going to be an embedded within the agent or external to it and then now because you are dealing with
distributed uh APIs and embedded memory now you have to worry about replication
and failover so that you can deal with agents that fail um or even regions that
fail on you and with agentic systems now you're talking about multiple services communicating over a protocol that's
durable execution with workflows distributed tracing and auditing um they
have to be able to do discovery and mesh networking so that they can communicate perhaps over um uh over over
disconnected networks and there are a number of emerging multi- aent protocols
that uh allow for discovery and back and forth communication between agents that
are collaborating uh particularly Google's 80 and B.AI AI was recently

so what's really going on here and one of the biggest issues and we're going to there's really three issues with what
people cited as why they don't get there is one the uncertainty of it all how do you trust these systems the second is a
security related issue and the third is scaling these systems and scaling is directly related to the cost of running
them and when it comes to uncertainty what you have to recognize is that LLMs
no matter how much you constrain them are a stochastic algorithm and because
it's a stoastic algorithm that means it is randomized and because it's randomized then there is a variance
associated with it and so uh you can manage that variance you can constrain
that variance you can restrict that variance um but that variance will
always be present uh and so the first you know kind of principle in how you're
thinking about these systems is that you must just open up the idea that you have
to embrace this uncertainty you have to accept that these systems are going to fail and then you also have to embrace
the randomness and design a system that anticipates failure and expects
randomness as opposed to trying to avoid it or eliminate it in at the end of the
day now um there's all sorts of little interesting points here but a couple of things I'll just point out is that when
you go into a multi- aent system you are now compounding the randomness
uh you know and if you're going to design a system where there is a whole sequence of agents that are uh working
in a pipeline uh you know it's going to become an exponential level of variance
that you have to deal with that's one big thing and then the second thing and you're going to hear this we're going to
say this over and over again um the best systems are those systems that uh embrace an evaluation uh driven
development approach meaning that you need to incorporate evaluation from the beginning you need to do it during your
development and you need to have it in production as well and that's because when you're giving an LLM or an input
into an LLM uh you're going to get a variance of responses on that it is not
possible to write an asserte equals so evaluation is the technique on which
you're going to use to quantify observe and verify whether the system is
maintaining its accuracy within acceptable levels um so this is really about a mindset that we're encouraging
you to embrace and you want to bake this mindset into the very beginning of your project
furthermore uh if the portion of the system that you're dealing with has
human input or is accessing critical data from your database or an event
stream uh there are a whole wide spectrum of security concerns that you
now need to embrace and the the most common way that we've been able to come
up with a metaphor for this is thinking of it as a leak or a leaky seed and the reason being is that uh the LLM are not
thinking they're not they are just pattern matching algorithms there and so
you can actually write prompts or a user can give information back to an LLM that
could accidentally expose information that you had no intention of exposing
because that LLM is pulling from a rich history of associations
um uh that that could cause it to ultimately leak or uh feel like it's a
ceive and so there is a whole new class of security vulnerabilities that you
have to anticipate and deal with and now we're starting to see that there are controls that you can put in place and

minimum access policies and so this is an emerging field uh but this work of
kind of min constraint of the data um is going to be how you deal with your data
sovereignty and compliance
issues and then lastly and we find this just so fascinating in that uh we
actually think of Agentic as the fifth uh fifth wave of compute and and the

the transactions per second on top of the fact that these LLMs are

systems for reliability I'd suggest sort of this this sort of process the first is just execute your standard domain
driven design process and add on an AIdriven design process which makes you aware um of all
the different nuances of deploying large language models which are hideously expensive slow and stochastic and I'll
talk a little bit more about them in a minute um second step is to define your data sovereignty and scope we've talked
about how LLMs are only as good as the data you supply it and so that context
typically contains data that's pretty sensitive and subject to compliance regulations or company policies and so

other question is to establish your evaluation strategy and I'll talk a little bit more about how you should

at least a draft of them you can then start having a discussion around what are the right AI models and there's a
lot of different choices right there are a lot of different types of models ranging from reasoning models to small language models which are more effective
to domain models that are fine-tuned for specific purposes most likely you may
end up using more than one model um once you have sort of a general sense of the
right AI models it's about selecting the Gentic platform architecture you don't want each agent to be doing things its
own way that for makes for impossible for you to actually code and manage that
and more importantly you can't orchestrate agents if you don't have a common orchestration framework so you really need to think about all the
different requirements to manage this distributed system of agents and then
after all this is when you can actually start building a developer workflow starting building your agents and then
you go through the deployment process and you think about observability and that's a loop that will run sort of
indefinitely as you add more features deploy them find bugs deploy them and so
forth so the core thing with AIdriven design
is really about how you have techniques to reduce uncertainty and there are three I would say main techniques that
I'd highlight the first is to create layers of certainty so instead of
delegating everything to a large language model which would be very slow and very expensive with a high degree of
variance you want to think about how you create layers of certainty um where
you're very confident that this will actually produce a desired outcome or it
will help you ground the LLM back into reality because if you periodically ground the LLM your overall variance is
actually reduced that's the first thing um the second thing is to incre in incorporate eval driven development very
similar to test driven development you want to continuously test and evaluate in development and production how your
agentic system is performing around a across a very wide range of inputs and finally um you want to choose
an Aentic AI platform that you know can operate your services scalably and
safely right and so that means things like distributed orchestration event- driven architecture streaming integrated
memory because all these things are actually requirements for you to build an agentic system
so when I talk about creating layers of certainty um there are five sort of general techniques probably more but I
think there are five common techniques um the first one Tyler mentioned earlier human in the loop right so you can
actually delegate decisions to human in the workflow so the LM may come up with a set of recommendations and then you
can ask a human to approve or reject that recommendation or ask the human for feedback so that's a common way to
actually ground things um the second which is actually getting extremely popular is agentic awareness you can
actually tell an LLM to spend more time thinking or when it's not sure to give
you three different options and then to score those three options and there's a lot of research right now that shows
that by allocating more test time compute or thinking time um when you're
asking an question you can dramatically improve performance um a third uh technique to create layers
of certainty is to actually get a second opinion from another agent right so maybe you get the output from agent one
and you might have a trust and safety agent or a style agent that's enforcing
the style guide of your company to check um check that and that's actually a very
common approach um where you have these these sort of checks and balances in a second agent right or using open AI to
check the output even if um the the output itself was generated by llama 4
um fourth technique is specialization so you can limit LLMs to making decisions
in their area of expertise so I've been using this implicitly you know there's the trust and safety LLM there's the
translation LLM but the more you can narrow the scope of responsibly of the LLM the lower the
variance and finally you can limit LM to a finite set of outcomes right so you
can say give me the output in a structured schema for machine processing give me a choice between five different
options and you can actually say you know and and this is very common you you can say instead of saying what do you
think about this what do you think on a score of 1 to five and that constrains the decisions to a numerical score from
1 to five which can actually which inherently reduces variance
except when it gets the score wrong except when it gets score wrong exactly so what do we mean by evaluation driven
development well so when you're actually sending something to an LLM you typically are assembling that context
you're adding it to your prompt you're sending it to your model then after the model the model's given result you're
actually processing that response you may if the model gives you multiple responses you're picking what you think
is the best response you may add some additional guard rails and so the question is when you send something all

Richard so uh model context protocol is a common protocol for you to for agents
to actually get access to what are commonly known as tools so being able to
extend your agent to operate a Salesforce API or retrieve content from
a Postgress database so that's really what MCP is it's about getting more context um or capabil adding more skills
to your agent a to A is a protocol proposed by Google which is about how
agents actually interoperate with each other so MCP is really scoped to how an agent sort of interacts with other
systems and A to A is a protocol around how agents discover and cooperate and
hand off um data so the two of them are very complimentary and not competitive
